data.title: Some Known Still Codes Part 2: Codes starting with numbers
data.text:
Of course, the easiest way to identify a photo is if the identification is printed on the photo. Visit this page for examples.

Most stills will have a number or letter sequence, which identifies the film, and a dash and the still number for that film. To match the still to the film, you must know the studio that produced the film. Even if you don't know the studio, you may be able to infer it from the stars portrayed in the still. For example, a Mary Pickford movie from the 1910's is probably a Paramount film.

Some independant producers just numbered their stills sequentially. For example, D.W. Griffith numbered his stills for Intolerance (1916) and Broken Blossoms (1919) that way. Some studios used letters and number codes. For example "FORD-11" is the eleventh film that John Ford directed for Fox.

Robert Birchard's book King Cowboy: Tom Mix and the Movies lists the still codes for most of Mix's movies. Also, thanks to Mr. Birchard for helping me identify some of my early Paramount stills. Warren M. Sherk's book The Films of Mack Sennett: Credit Documentation from the Mack Sennett Collection at the Margaret Herrick Library lists still codes for most Mack Sennett films, plus others like Triangle Komedies that he was associated with in name only. Jon Mirsalis has listed still codes for Lon Chaney films on his Lon Chaney home page .

The codes below were gleaned from the stills in my collection that I have identified, and from silent film books that I own. Thanks to Richard Koszarski for supplying me with the Goldwyn and MGM still codes. Thanks to Derek Boothroyd to supplying many of these codes that he found in his still collection.

Click here to see still codes that start with letters, which are on the next page.
